February 1, 2004: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
ABSOLUTE FRIENDS, by John le Carr√©. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) An Englishman
whose career in espionage ended with the fall of the Berlin Wall is reunited in
southern Germany with a onetime fellow spy.
THE AMATEUR MARRIAGE, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $24.95.) Sixty years of the
American experience, as seen through the lives of one mismatched couple.
NEW SPRING: The Novel, by Robert Jordan. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95.) The
11th volume of the "Wheel of Time" fantasy series.
RETREAT, HELl! by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) The 10th novel in the
series "The Corps" concerns the struggle of United States marines in the Korean
War.
THE BIG BAD WOLF, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) After joining
the F.B.I., Alex Cross must contend with numerous brazen kidnappings and a
ruthless criminal known as the Wolf.
MR. PARADISE, by Elmore Leonard. (Morrow, $25.95.) A Detroit police detective
investigates a double murder at the home of a retired lawyer.
THE LADY AND THE UNICORN, by Tracy Chevalier. (Dutton, $23.95.) The
fictional story behind the creation of a famous late-15th-century tapestry series.
EMMA'S SECRET, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) An
Englishwoman discovers the wartime diaries of her grandmother, who went on to
head a vast business empire.
ODD THOMAS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $26.95.) A short-order cook who can
communicate with the dead receives a portent of impending catastrophe.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Atria, $17.95.) A Harvard scholar tries to
save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
TRUTH OR DARE, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Putnam, $24.95.) In Whispering
Springs, Ariz., an interior designer with a supernatural talent and her husband, a
private investigator, are both haunted by their pasts.
POMPEII, by Robert Harris. (Random House, $24.95.) In A.D. 79, a young Roman
February 1, 2004
Non-Fiction
THE PRICE OF LOYALTY, by Ron Suskind. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A view
inside the Bush administration from the perspective of Paul O'Neill, the president's
first Treasury secretary.
MY PRISON WITHOUT BARS, by Pete Rose with Rick Hill. (Rodale, $24.95.) A
memoir by the former player who was banned from baseball for betting on games
while he was the manager of the Cincinnati Reds.
AMERICAN DYNASTY, by Kevin Phillips. (Viking, $25.95.) The political
commentator details a "pattern of deception" in four generations of the Bush
family.
DUDE, WHERE'S MY COUNTRY? by Michael Moore. (Warner, $24.95.) The
author of "Stupid White Men" calls for "regime change" in Washington.
LIES (AND THE LYING LIARS WHO TELL THEM), by Al Franken. (Dutton,
$24.95.) A satirical critique of the rhetoric of right-wing pundits and politicians.
CLIMBING HIGHER, by Montel Williams with Lawrence Grobel. (New American
Library, $25.95.) The television talk show host describes his battle with multiple
sclerosis.
THE ENEMY WITHIN, by Michael Savage. (WND Books, $27.99.) The syndicated
radio talk show host sets out to rebuff "the liberal assault on our schools, faith and
military."
THE PRIVILEGE OF YOUTH, by Dave Pelzer. (Dutton, $21.95.) The author of "A
Child Called 'It' " and "The Lost Boy" remembers his teenage years.
WHO'S LOOKING OUT FOR YOU? by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $24.95.) The host
of "The O'Reilly Factor" attacks those individuals and institutions that he believes
have let down the American people.
FLYBOYS, by James Bradley. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) An account of eight
American airmen who were shot down and captured by the Japanese in World
War II.
DOWN AND DIRTY PICTURES, by Peter Biskind. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.)
The story behind the Sundance Film Festival, Miramax and the rise of
independent movies.
AN END TO EVIL, by David Frum and Richard Perle. (Random House, $25.95.) A
former presidential speechwriter and a former assistant secretary of defense
describe "how to win the war on terror."
